I don't know, I LOVED Sarah in Cagayan and was rooting for her over Tony, Aubry is one of my favorite contestants of all time, and Cirie is a legend who is still playing, meanwhile I wasn't a big malcolm fan premerge and wasn't sad to see JT go either. Yeah that would make sense to me, like they believe that by purging the bad people in the world or something they're going to earn forgiveness and also be taken (would you kill a baby to cure a cancer?), and the guise they're putting up is that they are helping those people talk to their loved ones, which they technically are because they are dying.

She's memorable because she gave funny confessionals and was great at challenges. No one seems to really remember what she was actually like in MvGX because her personality was shadowed by her blindside.

I completely agree with the first bit and I think it's why seasons like Cambodia, MvGX, and now this one are somewhat dull. The thing about strategy is that there's only so much new strategy you can watch that is exciting and fresh. After 34 seasons of it, it gets old. So if the season is focused on only strategy or all the players care about is playing a highly strategic game, it becomes boring to watch because you're essentially just watching 10 people decide what alliance they want to be in and play some idols.
What makes Survivor interesting is the personal drama and the social dynamics, and that's something that is sorely lacking when all of the players view it only as a strategic game that they want to win no matter the cost.
at least spencer knew when to make a move and when to sit back
I really hope this doesn't happen. That feels way too neat and tidy of an ending to be on this show.
I love it too. I wasn't a big fan of MvGX's but this season is the first time I've really noticed and enjoyed the music.

Yes, it's not about the backstabbing, it's about him being one of her only two friends and then one being gone.

Say it with me: just because you fall down the stairs doesn't mean you should throw yourself the rest of the way down. Even if it is true that no one would make long term plans with Zeke, which I highly doubt, that's not a rationale to blow up his game even more.

Yeah it's scary how quickly people buy his excuses. I should be more used to this sub being fickle by now, but it's like people don't even try to evaluate any information, they just buy it instantly. Do they not think Zeke might be biased, or lying, about why he went out and why he did what he did? I just wish people would take it with a grain of salt.
No, she didn't. She felt sad because she lost a friend.
Or at least make amends with them once you fail instead of being like "they're the last person I want to work with right now..." and go off talking to people in the minority alliance.

His second biggest problem is that he lacks adaptability which is key to survivor. He wasn't able to learn from the mistakes of his first season, he wasn't able to soothe Andrea after he targeted her (and also wasn't able to get her out), and he wasn't able to just shut up and be a part of an alliance at a time in the game in which throwing out people's names is very dangerous.
Him saying that no one would win against him in the F3 really made me want him to make it to F3 just so he could be a goat.

Oh so you suddenly have the ability to read the minds of Sarah Lacina, Andrea Boehlke, and Cirie Fields circa June 2016, and know that they didn't have intentions of bringing Zeke to the end?
Fuck off, I make conclusions based on the evidence I have in front of me so unless you have some sort of evidence to support your stupid ass claims I don't have time to entertain your comments.
To be fair she would've been sent home if her tribe lost at all in the premerge.
You analyze the entire thing *in order*. You have no understanding of how stories work at all.
Michaela didn't violate a universal moral standard or even a personal moral standard. Her feeling affinity to Zeke does not mean she thought it was wrong to vote him out.
Don't call me sweetheart asshat. The main *character*. She's a fictional entity. You can't use her as evidence of real-life teens being blinded by anger you delusional prick.

His alliances were fine going into the merge what the fuck are you talking about. Andrea and Cirie were completely willing to work with him, and Sarah talked about how her perception of Zeke in the game didn't change at all. Are you even watching this season?

He wasn't targeted at all though? Andrea and crew were fine to go along with Zeke, they were telling him their plans to get out Brad/Sierra and everything. Zeke being "targeted" at the merge is part of the narrative he created himself to protect his ego.
He's good at making friends, that's it. A good social player also has social awareness and adaptability, two things Zeke lacks.
One scene that takes place after all of those other scenes. The ending is more important than anything else.
The only difference is that Kass blew up her game last time. If Kass were playing this game too, she probably would do the same thing.
Yes. Being a teenager who is pissed off at the world doesn't mean you're blind to any sort of rational thought or completely stupid.
That's not what guilt is

This is a season called Game Changers, with Zeke "evolution of the game" Smith and Hali "I'm giving my vote to the person who was running things" Ford on the jury. Troyzan is playing a decent game in a vacuum but you're failing to take into account any context.

because at that point he had already held up the plane for a long time.

No I'm arguing both of those things. You're right this wasn't what my argument was about originally, but that's what you made it about in your comment. I'm not presenting a fucking thesis here I'm responding to each of your comments on an individual basis as you send them to me.
And no, that wasn't even what I was arguing at first. I said that they aren't responsible for people *irrationally thinking* that the show glamorizes suicide.

The crazy thing about Sarah is that she's seemingly playing the exact same game she did in Cagayan, only this time it's working. Playing the middle is working for her right now, but as Aubry said in Kaoh Rong, sometimes the guy in the middle of the road gets run over.
I don't think it's that he's not there, just that the edit isn't showing him to us, much like Tasha.

She's quietly worked her way to the top in this game, sitting at the right hand of Cirie but at the same time I don't think people will view her as a threat as soon as they will Cirie. Her edit, on the other hand...

She seemed to redeem herself somewhat this week, and people aren't as aggravated by her. Although I'm not sure how smart it was to show what a challenge beast she is on a challenge she didn't actually win, and that was for reward in the first place.

He blew up his game two episodes ago and he could never swallow his pride enough to save face. Zeke really cemented himself as an awful player this season. He's good at making friends, but that's about it.
Whozan?
Good social awareness in seeing how Zeke was wrapping Brad around his finger, and she won immunity. Deserves player of the week in my opinion.
I've never rolled my eyes at a comment so hard before. Your attempts at being patronizing are pathetically transparent.
Well he shouldn't have booked a red eye flight with a baby??? Or he shouldn't have tried to put the baby in a seat he bought for a different person???
Alright go ahead and pretend you're some airplane expert but those policies are in a place for a reason. Sometimes there are more important things than "human decency", like, I don't know, security.

She says near the beginning of the video something along the lines of "well this seat is under the name X" then he's like "yeah well I payed for it" or something like that. Did you even watch the video?
Her job wasn't to help them, her job was to do her job and uphold the rules. She wanted to help them on a human level, but that went against her job so she couldn't.

Yeah, no, that's not how literally anything in this world works. Have fun living a delusional life where you always end up the victim because you don't realize the universe doesn't revolve around you.

It's not glamorizing it though. What's already been established here is that any perception of "glamorization" in this situation is in the eye of the beholder. I'd much, much rather a show be brutally honest about suicide like this one was, than to pussyfoot around it and make it look like an even more romantic and nonviolent thing.
That's okay, I'll just pretend like I got gold
She couldn't break the rules for one person who thought they were above them. Sorry but rules are there for a reason and "common sense" isn't a good enough excuse to break them.
That part was stupid (was that the same chick I thought they were different people?) but by the end I think she was being the more reasonable one. Both of them are to blame in this situation though.

Because that's what Hannah thought. The show's point isn't that that is the only way to get justice, it's that we need to start making there be other ways to get justice. It's about impacting change not inspiring people to act the same.
Well that's not the responsibility of the people who made it. People could have some crazy irrational reaction to anything, that doesn't mean we should just stop making TV shows.
I think you're underestimating 14-16 year olds. Just because you were impressionable or irrational doesn't mean all are.
Yeah seriously. I've had suicidal thoughts before and it's hard to describe but watching that suicide scene...made me want to a lot less.

Yeah, hi, someone who actually has depression and suicidal thoughts here, I can assure you that this show did *not* glamorize suicide. It made suicide horrifying, painful, traumatic...it did not glamorize it. Hell, this stupid ass video seems to glamorize depression more than this series ever did.

I thought she was pretty reasonable. She wanted to help them but there was nothing she could do.

Sticking to the rules you abide by is not being an unreasonable prick. This guy though is an entitled douche for expecting a company to conform to his desires even though they went against the company's policy.
couldn't he just have asked for a refund or voucher or something and flown with the baby in arms? It seems like this entire situation could've been easily avoided.

It's not so much about them being close friends, it's about the comfort. When you're in as crazy of a situation as Survivor, you look for any sort of comfort, including emotional comfort, possible. Having a shared history with someone like that, and having had that person in your life for the past three months, even just in the periphery, when everything else is changing and is constantly uneasy and paranoid, has to be comforting, and so it's understandable when that comfort is stripped to be emotional.
